title: Hemispheric Asymmetries in Categorical Perception of Orientation in Infants and Adults
abstractText:
Categorical perception is when a continuum is grouped into categories and distortions in perceptual judgments are seen.  For example, judging the difference between two colours from different categories (eg blue and green) is easier than judging the difference between two colours from the same category, even when the difference for same- and different category colours is equated.  Categorical perception is seen for many types of continua, and the effect is found even in infants. 

The challenge is to understand how the brain does this.  Recent research suggests that, in adults, the left side of the brain contributes more to categorical perception of colour than the right.  In contrast, in infants, the right side of the brain contributes more to categorical perception of colour than the left.  This raises questions about the contribution of the two sides of the brain to categorisation across development. 

The main aim of the current project is to see whether these findings generalise to categorical perception of another domain, by investigating the contribution of the left and right side of the brain to categorical perception of orientation in both infants and adults.  This will have implications for understanding how infants and adults categorise the visual world.
